Turning to the merits, the trial court held as a matter law that where there is a test case, where there is one defendant among similarly situated other defendants and a prosecution of law only against the one, but that is legally insufficient, there were not factual findings as -- as the Ohio Supreme Court noted on the footnote at the end of it's opinion.
There -- there were no factual findings by the trial court about bad faith, bad motives, cartoons, anything.
It simply stated that it was legally insufficient to have a test case.

Now, my brother Mr. Fahringer has sort of waffled in his point this morning, but in his reply writ at page five, he concedes now begrudgingly that a test case is an appropriate as prosecutorial stratagem.

That concession is well warranted in light of this decision -- this Court's decisions on Mackay Telegraph, Moog Industries and Universal-Rundle Corp, which were all cited in the briefs, as well as many other cases.

Where there are just numerous defendants similarly situated and the prosecutor lacks resources to prosecute all, or where the law is at some question whether there is -- whether the laws can be applied to a particular kind of situation or particular kind of defendant.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That situation, could he select his defendant because of the cartoon he published?
What is your view on that?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: No, I think he could select him randomly, and the courts have so held.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But could he?
Could he do it because of the cartoon?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He could not do it.
He could select --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You would agree he could not do that?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: If the cartoon is constitutionally protected and he was doing because he was punishing for an exercise of constitutional right, we would agree that would be inappropriate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's not the question.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's not the question here.
Because here, it seems to me that the evidence is unequivocal as to what happenned.
There were complaints made about the July Hustler issue, some of those complaints focused on the cartoon, some of them focused on the magazine as a whole.
But even assuming that every complaint focused on the cartoon and that spurred an investigation, it is not -- it's simply irrelevant in an equal protection case (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Let me ask you one other question.
Let's assume that it was not the sole reason but that the only disguising factor from all other magazines, and it was one of the reasons, would that be permissible?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: I believe it would be if --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It would be if it was one of reason.
But it always has some other reason, why then, it's a -- it's a test case.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's exactly right.

And in the -- in the Court's equal protection cases, Mt.Healthy against Doyle, Justice Powell's opinion for the Court in Bakke, in Arlington Heights footnote 21, the Court has repeatedly stated that “where in an equal protection case, the moving party, here the petitioners, have established that invidious or discriminate, intentionally discriminatory reason is the motivating cause for a particular kind of state action,” -- and we don't have that here, we have -- did not establish that -- “Then the burden shifts to the state to show that the invidious factors not the “but for” cause.”
So that is -- that is the test.
Here, we don't -- I don't believe that we get to the “but for” problem.

If we do, I think that the prosecutor's testimony at the hearing overwhelmingly shows that the decision to prosecute was made on various rational factors, including his view that Hustler has more obscene, the fact that was a more notorious violator of the law, the fact that was in-state and even if you could get extradition over these other out-of-state publishers, there was no need for Cleveland to expend that additional money in bringing a test case to pick the most difficult to prosecute.
As the Chief had said earlier today, he can pick the strongest case and he can pick the easiest case for himself, that's entirely appropriate.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: He can also pick -- can he, can he pick one he just doesn't like?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, if he -- then the question goes to me --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Say there's ten ad he's going to pick one, and he said, “Well, they're all absolutely equal they're all be valid prosecutions, I'm going to pick the one I like the least.”

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or in this case the one that defends the prosecutor the most.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, certainly, where he --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Or what if he had to pick the one that he has the dad most protests about.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That is entirely appropriate because it's an aim of the criminal law not only to punish, but to deter.

And in so -- insofar as the particular defendant has the most notoriety and therefore the effect of a conviction will be most telling on the future compliance, certainly picking out the most notorious offender is perfectly appropriate.
And in certain cases like tax cases, for example, where there's a protester who has willfully violated the laws, his public statements will facilitate the prosecution.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, if he says that, “In my next campaign, I will get further if I go after this magazine rather than another?”

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, one would hope that the prosecutorial decision making was not made on --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That isn't what I -- it isn't what I asked you, what about that?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: I don't think --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would have us understand that in tax cases and regulatory cases, as you would, in cases involving publications magazine and newspapers?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Yes, I --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You could say the same breadth of discretion and the prosecutor published -- prosecuting those papers because he doesn't like editorial point of view, for example?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, that's -- I mean -- they would enforce, obviously -- an obvious First Amendment defenses.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But under your answer as I understand it, that's perfectly permissible.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But what's he prosecuting him for?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: “We don't like the kind of editorials they've been writing we'll prosecute them?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He's prosecuting -- no, no, no.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What's he prosecuting him for?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's right, that's the question.
Here he is prosecuting for an obscene (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You're prosecuting him for a crime that all the other newspapers are committing the same way, they want to do some (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You can't prosecute him for printing the editorial.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: No, he's not --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You just -- you just picked him out for that reason, it's all.
You don't prosecute anybody who doesn't write such an editorial.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: No, no, it's the sole --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You're probably prosecuting the newspaper for tax evasion, or for something else.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: And -- and the sole reason that you wouldn't have prosecuted but for a particular editorial, that it seems to me might be inappropriate.
But if he would have prosecuted --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- on -- on your answers to Justice White.
You said he doesn't like him and that's all that counts.
And he may not like him because of the editorials.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, if it -- if his intent is to silence a constitutional right, or if it is an invidious race-based or religious-based or other arbitrary kind of base -- basis for the prosecution and it's the -- that the soul -- and it's a product of that kind of invidious, kind arbitrary or irrational discrimination, then you have problem.
That was not even the -- the conclusory allegations in -- in this case did not even warrant a hearing.
He admitted that he had no idea what the -- what the proof was going to show when the prosecutor took the stand.
I mean in our view under federal law, a hearing was not even necessary in this case.
The hearing did show however, quite conclusively, that this prosecution was perfectly permissible and rationally chosen.
And we think that more difficult cases, you know, might arise, this is certainly not one of those cases.

The other point that I would like to make about the -- that the cartoon, if, Justice Stevens, you were right that insofar as the prosecution was based that all in the cartoon, that it would be an impermissible prosecution, then anytime you had a complaining witness who brought, I see my time -- okay, this is --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Finish your sentence.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Thank you.

Anytime you had a complaining witness who believed or brought the -- the crimes to the notice of the police because they didn't like the defendant, let's assume it's a drug pusher or -- or a bank robber, or whatever --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And this case involves a publication, let's -- let's have examples of either newspapers or magazines.
I'm sure the difference in armed robbery and burglary --

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, for --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- would be entirely different.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: -- for example, suppose -- suppose the -- an employee at the -- at the -- at a newspaper or not even an employee, a person who knows --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, that's right --

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: -- that there's discrimination --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let's say an editorial writer, state -- give us a case involving an editorial writer.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Fine.

The -- the person who reports the violations of Labor Standard Act, or some other -- or tax evasion, does so, a private person, because he has a dislike for the editorial policy of a particular paper, it is invidious state action which violates the Equal Protection Clause.
The private motivation of the reporting party which leads the investigation is simply irrelevant.
And -- and therefore --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would it be irrelevant if the record were clear that there were about 200 other people just like this one that they had never prosecuted in here?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Yes, completely relevant.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
Do you have anything further, Mr. Fahringer?
You have two minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: herald_price_fahringer
turn.label: Mr. Herald Price Fahringer
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) Your Honor, thank you.
I wanted to bring to the Court's attention, what the judge -- the trial judge said at the very end of the case.

"For purpose of this motion, the Court is limited by the testimony and must search that testimony objectively in relationship to the constitutional guidelines established by a series of previous judicial decisions on the discriminatory prosecution question.
And it is this Court's decision that the testimony supports the allegations of the defendant.”

So, I believe, Your Honors, that language can be interpreted albeit -- albeit a very short decision that the judge did make a finding, a fact-finding, a -- a decision that the testimony in general supported our claim.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the -- the Supreme Court of Ohio didn't agree with them.

turn.speaker: herald_price_fahringer
turn.label: Mr. Herald Price Fahringer
turn.text: That's true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's the -- that's the decision that's binding on us, isn't it?

turn.speaker: herald_price_fahringer
turn.label: Mr. Herald Price Fahringer
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I would like believe -- and again, I apologize for disagreeing with you that I think when the -- in -- in the dissent when they say we have always given great weight to the -- the trier of the fact, and -- and this Court too has given great weight to the trier of the fact in the past, I think that should be done here.

Last, let me just say this, if it is part of the reason, if the First Amendment implications are part of the reason for prosecuting the magazine, then it seems to me there has to be a much more in-depth inquiry than we had here as to whether or not this is a test case or not.

Once the concession is made that it was part of the reason why we went after this magazine, then I don't think it's sufficient simply to label it a test case, but that there should be some corroboration of it being a test case.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
